1 
I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.      The proposed capacity development technical assistance (TA) aims to support the 
development of Cambodia’s oil and gas industry to allow the government its due share of sector 
revenue while also fostering greater private sector participation in upstream and downstream 
operations. Prior support from the Asian Development Bank to the regulator, the Cambodian 
National Petroleum Authority (CNPA), has helped to fund an analysis of CNPA's strategic 
functions,  a  road  map  for  development  of  upstream  and  downstream  petroleum  sector 
operations in the country and an outline for a combined upstream and downstream petroleum 
law. A second ADB TA1 provided on-the-job training and advice to the CNPA counterpart staff 
and advice and guidance on IT needs and the installation of the basic IT equipment and 
services during 2008-2010. All indications are that the first set of production permits will be 
issued  in  the  near  term  and  oil  revenues  are  to  begin  accruing  to  the  government.  The 
government has requested ADB’s continued assistance to help strengthen the CNPA’s staff 
capacity.  Specifically,  the  TA  will:  (i)  help  prepare  key  technical  analyses  and  operating 
guidelines, such as contractual and fiscal regimes and inter-agency coordination protocols, and 
undertake  workforce  planning  assessments,  (ii)  develop  and  roll  out  an  institutional 
development plan, and (iii) provide training, along with such knowledge resources as computer 
equipment and software, to enhance staff skills and managerial capacity. In addition, the TA 
program  will  serve  as  a  coordinating  platform2 and  help  integrate  the  delivery  of  future 
assistance  to  the  sector  planned  by  several  development  partners  and  the  private  sector. 
Institutional  strengthening  of the  CNPA  is  well-aligned  with  the  priorities  of  ADB’s  country 
operations  business  plan  (COBP)3,  which  are  to  promote  good  governance,  institutional 
capacity  building,  and  the  development  of  an  enabling  environment  for  private  sector 
development. The TA will expand the CNPA’s capacity to manage exploration and potential 
production of onshore oil and gas around the Tonle Sap region, which is a geographical focus of 
the COBP. The impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, and costs of the TA 
were finalized based on discussions with the CNPA.  The design and monitoring framework is in 
Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Development  of  extractive  industries  in  Cambodia  can  generate  valuable  foreign 
exchange for the country and help lift millions of the country’s citizens out of poverty. For this to 
happen, however, it is crucial that the sector be developed in line with principles of good 
governance, regulatory certainty, increased operational effectiveness, and prudent fiscal and 
financial management. Putting these elements in place will also encourage greater private 
sector participation. Development of certain natural resources in Cambodia has not necessarily 
always translated into long-term economic benefits for the citizens of the country.  
 
 
                                                
1 ADB, 2008. Technical Assistance to the Kingdom of Cambodia for Institutional Strengthening of Cambodian 
National Petroleum Authority, Manila (TA 4901-CAM).  
2 Under the previous TA, ADB had established a development partners group comprising The World Bank, Australian 
Agency for International Development, Norwegian Agency for Development Cooperation, the United Nations 
Development Programme (UNDP), among others. This group was to facilitate better coordination and has been 
meeting regularly to review progress under the various donor-support programs relating to the petroleum sector 
and also review progress being made by CNPA on the milestones established under its roadmap. It is expected 
that the TA will utilize this development partners group as a key instrument for continued coordination.  
3  ADB, 2009. Country Operations Business Plan (2009-2012), Manila.

2            
 
3.  Growing interest in the country’s nascent oil and gas sector provides a new opportunity 
to develop an extractive industry that can contribute to broad-based economic development. If 
properly managed by a national public agency, the industry could attract more private sector 
investment and diversify the country’s energy supplies. Most importantly, this would create a 
new  revenue  stream  for  the  government—through  royalties,  corporate  income  taxes,  and 
production sharing—and these revenues could then be invested in health, education, social 
services for the country’s people and the development of the agriculture and infrastructure 
sectors.  
 
4.  Cambodia’s geology and exploration indicate petroleum accumulations, although drilling 
continues and the extent of recoverable reserves is not yet known. Factors that point to at least 
some economically viable extraction potential include: (i) onshore natural oil seepages; (ii) the 
presence of sedimentary rocks in several basins; and geological structures that may trap and 
hold oil and gas in reservoirs, and (iii) the similarity between the geology of Cambodia and that 
of adjacent areas in Viet Nam and Thailand where oil and gas have been found and are being 
produced.  The  country’s  prospective  offshore  extraction  areas  have  been  divided  into  six 
offshore petroleum blocks for selected contractors and some conditional petroleum agreements 
have been granted by both Cambodia and Thailand (conditional) in a seventh offshore area 
where Cambodia’s claims overlap those of Thailand.  Onshore oil and gas exploration blocks 
have been awarded in 19 areas, three of which have been allocated to contractors in and 
around the Tonle Sap Basin.  
 
5.  The most advanced exploration work has been in offshore block A, where 27 wells have 
been drilled; 18 of them by Chevron starting in 2002. All but one of these wells showed the 
presence of hydrocarbons and several areas within the block have been identified as having 
hydrocarbon  deposits.  In  late  September  2010,  Chevron  applied  to  the  CNPA  for  an  oil 
production permit in block A.4 Current estimates of recoverable petroleum reserves are modest. 
However, initial development of even a very small, economically marginal oil accumulation of 10 
million barrels of recoverable oil would yield government revenues of about $200 million over a 
6-year period at a crude oil price of $75 per barrel. This would be equivalent to 20% of the 
annual development assistance pledges to Cambodia by various multilateral and bilateral aid 
agencies. Oil production is expected to begin in late 2012, with the government expecting to 
start receiving revenues from oil exports in 2013. Based on a current mean estimated ultimate 
recoverable oil reserve in block A of 60 million barrels, government revenue from the sector 
could be as high as $2 billion over a 20-year period. Cambodia is thus at the inception point of 
its petroleum industry, and will have to navigate through many complex technical issues and 
administrative issues.  
 
6.        The government recognizes the importance of good governance in effective development 
of  the  petroleum  sector  and  has  constituted  a  working  group  under  its  Council  for  the 
Development of Cambodia that comprises representatives from the Ministry of Economy and 
Finance and the CNPA. The development partners group led by ADB has been helping the 
CNPA and the government working group to implement the reforms that will allow the CNPA to 
negotiate with petroleum companies in a transparent manner.   
 
7.       Further reform will be necessary as the sector moves toward commercial activity. For 
example, the CNPA may decide to graduate from direct negotiation with contractors in awarding 
                                                
4 As of now, recoverable gas reserves in Cambodia do not warrant gas development but further exploration may lead 
to the discovery of more accumulations that could be aggregated for economic exploitation. This gas could replace 
expensive imported petroleum fuels currently used for power generation.

3 
offshore  blocks,  which  was  appropriate  during  early  resource  prospecting,  to  competitive 
bidding, as required by the Petroleum Regulations, 1991. When oil and gas production begins, 
the  CNPA  will  be  required  to  (i)  administer,  monitor,  and  regulate  petroleum  production 
operations; (ii) audit oil and gas production; (iii) determine royalties and production shares due 
the government; and (iv) vouch for the eligibility of costs for contractor’s cost recovery, pursuant 
to the petroleum agreements with private sector oil companies, as well as ensure compliance 
with environmental and safety regulations.  
 
8.        Earlier work by both ADB and the Australian Agency for International Development 
showed that several steps identified in a sector road map could not proceed without remedial 
measures on critical weaknesses in the CNPA and improvements in the coordination across 
relevant  government  ministries  and  agencies.  Of  particular  concern  are  fundamental 
deficiencies  in  organizational  management  and  staff  motivation  at  the  CNPA.  The  24 
recommendations that emerged out of ADB’s prior TAs emphasized the urgency of addressing 
these issues. Notwithstanding the reforms made by CNPA’s during 2009 and 2010, in order to 
be more effective, CNPA needs to improve its operational systems and processes, its ability to 
engage with and be informed by other government agencies, and the technical skills and 
management expertise of its staff.5  
 
9.       CNPA believes that expanding the oil and gas sector will deliver economic development 
benefits and it is preparing a request for further assistance under a coordinated program-based 
approach (PBA). The PBA will be based on the priority areas and recommendations identified in 
CNPA’s road map and the ADB TA’s recommendations and will adhere to the principles of 
harmonization  and  aid  effectiveness  under  the  Paris  Declaration  and  will  allow  individual 
development partners to bring their specific expertise to bear. The PBA is also intended to 
complement  and  build on  assistance that  is to  be  provided  by  private  sector  oil  and gas 
companies under their capacity building support funds6.  
 
10.      ADB proposes under this TA to continue its leadership role in facilitating dialogue among 
the stakeholders in Cambodia’s oil and gas sector and in helping ensure effective delivery of 
assistance from the members of the development partners group and the private sector to the 
CNPA and the industry as a whole.  It is expected that by the end of the current TA, oil 
production would have commenced in Cambodia and CNPA and the government would have 
the resources needed to fully support CNPA. Further, it is also likely the further assistance will 
be made available by the development partners in the near future. This TA will thus pave the 
way for a better resourced and more effective CNPA that is able to manage the country’s 
petroleum resources.  
 
 
                                                
5 Good management of the sector requires that competent professionals be deployed within the CNPA in the 
disciplines of petroleum geology, geophysics, geochemistry, petroleum engineering, and oil and gas regulation. 
Domestic service providers need professionals and tradesmen in construction-related areas such as high-quality 
welding and mechanical fabrication. Experience in other countries demonstrates that the petroleum sector regulator 
can play a pivotal role in promoting greater domestic industry involvement by working with national tertiary education 
institutions to align course offerings to the needs of the growing sector. 
 
6  The private oil companies under their petroleum exploration agreements with CNPA are required to set up aside 
funds for training and other capacity building support for CNPA and related ministries within the government of 
Cambodia. These funds are managed by the oil companies; however any proposed activities need to be endorsed 
by CNPA.

4            
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.       The impact of the TA is increased revenue from the oil and gas sector in Cambodia for 
overall economic development. The outcome will be enhanced institutional and staff capacity 
within the CNPA to perform its role as the regulator for Cambodia’s oil and gas sector. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.    The key outputs of the TA will include: (i) an effective contractual regime, including fiscal 
regimes  and  interagency  operation  protocols,  and  workforce  planning  measures  that 
complement  these  improvements  implemented;  and  (ii)  institutional  capacity  of  the  CNPA 
strengthened. Key activities under the first output  will include (i) petroleum economics analyses 
for upstream oil and gas operations, including an update of modeling of the effects of alternative 
contractual and fiscal regimes; (ii) formal interagency protocols for environmental and safety 
inspections and approvals; and (iii) workforce planning assessments and studies to determine 
Cambodia’s capacity to participate in the petroleum sector, including examination of sector 
manpower  needs  and  the  capacity  of  higher  and  vocational  education  to  meet  projected 
requirements. Key activities under the second output will include (i) creation of an institutional 
development plan and specific training of CNPA staff through an array of modalities on an as-
needed  basis,  including  on-the-job  training  and  mentoring  by  resident  expert  advisers;  (ii) 
development and delivery of short courses, certificate and diploma programs, and study tours or 
internships  at    private  companies  and  other  regulators;  and  (iii)  the  provision  of  books, 
periodicals, and audio-visual and interactive learning packages.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.    The cost of the TA is estimated at the equivalent of $440,000. ADB will provide the 
equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis from the Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). 
The grant will cover: (i) remuneration, travel, and per diem for the consultants; (ii) related 
training seminars and conferences; (iii) IT equipment, books and trainings aids, and (iv) CNPA’s 
support  and/or  overhead  costs.  The  government  will  finance  the  equivalent  of  $40,000 
remaining through its concomitant budgetary inputs to the CNPA.  The cost estimates and 
financing plan are in Appendix 2.   
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  The CNPA will be the executing agency. Within ADB, the TA will be  managed by 
Southeast Asia Department’s Energy and Water Division. All efforts will be made to fully involve 
other development partners involved in oil and gas sector activities in Cambodia through the 
existing working group. The TA consultants and ADB will also work to engage with the private 
sector to ensure that their capacity building support committed  to the CNPA and the sector 
align well with the TA activities. The TA scope, including key outputs, outcome, and impact, 
have  been  developed  in  close  consultation  with  the  CNPA  and  with  the  various  inter-
governmental  working  groups  it  has  constituted,  which  include  representatives  from  other 
government agencies concerned. 
 
15.  The key assumptions and risks are in the design and monitoring framework in Appendix 
1. It is assumed that broad-ranging management changes made within the CNPA in late 2009 
have  brought  the  institution  back  into  conformity  with  established  government  procedures,

5 
including adherence to prescribed procurement and financial requirements and the deployment 
of dedicated staff for such functions. It is also assumed that the government will continue to 
back  the  development  partners’  effort  to  implement  improved  governance  and  transparent 
operations in the oil and gas sector in Cambodia. The main risk is that the prospect of large 
returns in the near term could lead to rent seeking or non-transparent operations, as has 
happened in other countries.  
 
16.       The TA will require approximately 14 person-months of international consulting services. 
Given the specialized nature of the inputs required, the TA will be implemented by a team of 
individual international consultants supervised by the ADB project officer.  ADB's Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) will be followed in the selection of 
these consultants. The consultants will comprise a petroleum adviser, who will be engaged for 6 
person-months on an intermittent basis throughout the TA, and a series of thematic advisors. 
The terms of reference for petroleum adviser are in Appendix 2. The adviser will have broad and 
considerable petroleum sector experience and an extensive background in the development of 
national petroleum institutions. The thematic advisers will be engaged on an as-needed basis 
and upon the request of the CNPA to address particular issues and petroleum sector themes 
such as petroleum economics, petroleum production accounting, environmental management, 
petroleum  exploration  and  development,  petroleum  financing,  and  human  resources 
development. It is envisaged that an estimated 8 person-months of inputs would be required 
across the various disciplines. Terms of reference for each assignment will be prepared during 
implementation of the TA in consultation with the CNPA. Equipment required under the TA will 
be procured in accordance with ADB's Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to 
time), and will be turned over to the implementing agencies upon TA completion. Disbursements 
under  the  TA  will  be  done  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The TA will be implemented over a 2-year 
period from March 2011 to March 2013.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.      The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the government of the Kingdom of Cambodia for Capacity Building of the Cambodian National 
Petroleum Authority, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

10  Appendix 3   
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  As  the  Cambodian  National  Petroleum  Authority  (CNPA)  readies  itself  for  the 
development  of  Cambodia’s  first  offshore  oil  fields  and  embraces  expanded  petroleum 
exploration operations, the organization and its management need considerable professional 
advice and guidance. The help to be provided by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) is needed 
not only to make petroleum development planning and processing and exploration management 
more effective but also to ensure that the CNPA is fully capable of taking good care of the 
country’s petroleum assets and ensure that revenue from the sector is transparently accrued 
and is available for general economic development purposes. The CNPA needs an experienced 
petroleum  sector  advisor  who  will  provide  ongoing  responsible  advice  to  the  authority’s 
chairman, vice chairman, director-general, and the professional staff on an as needed basis. 
The advice provided under the technical assistance (TA) will support the CNPA in its efforts to (i) 
bring  about  Cambodia’s  initial  oil  field  development,  (ii)  manage  broadened  petroleum 
exploration efforts appropriately, and (iii) take additional steps toward institutional reform and 
strengthened capacity.  
 
A.  Detailed Tasks 
 
2.  The petroleum advisor will make periodic visits during implementation of the TA and will 
be based in Phnom Penh at the CNPA office during the in-country visits. The advisor will inter 
alia provide responsible sector advice and guidance, variously reporting to the chairman, vice 
chairman, director-general, and deputy directors-general of the CNPA, as required from time to 
time. He/she will provide guidance and advice on:  
 
(i)  best and appropriate institutional organization, processes, and coordination for 
best  practice  administration,  management,  regulation,  and  approval  by  the 
government of petroleum industry operations;  
(ii)  coordination  and  implementation  of  recommended  steps  towards  institutional 
reform and strengthening of the CNPA; 
(iii)  the operational development of the CNPA as an effective and well-managed 
petroleum agency in Cambodia; 
(iv)  relations and coordination of the management of petroleum operations between 
the CNPA and other government ministries and institutions;  
(v)  the best use of donor agencies in the provision of development assistance, by 
helping the CNPA coordinate and to prepare documentation for this assistance; 
(vi)  the appropriate legal, commercial, and economic terms for sector investment and 
operations; 
(vii)  technical aspects of sector exploration, development, production, and utilization 
projects and their operations; 
(viii)  opportunities, concepts, schemes, and plans for the development of identified 
and new oil and gas fields; 
(ix)  sector permits, approvals, negotiations; and 
(x)  overall sector institutional arrangements, including the development of a national 
oil company and state participation in sector development. 
 
3.  The advisor will also develop a list of required IT equipment, software, books, and other 
training  aids  and  procure  it  in  consultation  with  the  executing  agency  and  as  per  ADB 
guidelines.

Appendix 3  11 
 
B.  Outputs and Reporting Requirements 
 
4.  At the end of each periodic visit to the CNPA, and as otherwise requested, the petroleum 
sector advisor will provide written briefs to ADB Cambodia Resident Mission and the project 
officer, Energy and Water Division, Southeast Asia Department. 
 
5.  The petroleum sector advisor will maintain a confidential file of all advisory memoranda, 
thematic  papers,  spreadsheets, models,  presentations,  and  any  other  documents  prepared 
during the provision of the advisory services to the CNPA, which may be made available to ADB 
as commercial-in-confidence documents for gauging the advisor’s performance only. 
 
6.  The petroleum sector advisor will provide coordination between CNPA, ADB, and other 
development partners and donors for further development assistance that may benefit the 
development of the petroleum sector and the CNPA as the lead institution. 
 
7.  The  petroleum  advisor  will  report  any  important  situations,  events,  and/or  changes 
occurring within the Cambodian petroleum sector, the CNPA, or other involved ministries and 
institutions of the government.  
 
8.  Specific deliverables will be the coordination and finalization of the following key TA 
reports:  
 
(i)  preparation of an inception report, including the capacity development approach, 
within 1 month of TA commencement; 
(ii)  preparation of a preliminary report on the key issues for strengthening capacity at 
the CNPA by end of 3 months; and 
(iii)  completion of the report on the capacity development of the CNPA by December 
2012, after completion of dissemination workshops. 
 
C.  Delivery of services 
 
9.  It is envisaged that periodic visits of about 2 weeks each every 6 or 7 weeks will be 
made by the petroleum advisor during the period of engagement.  
 
D.  Qualifications 
 
10.  The  petroleum  sector  advisor  shall  have  qualifications  in  appropriate  technical 
disciplines, with at least a master’s degree and a minimum of 25 years of experience in the 
petroleum industry, particularly in the administration of the petroleum sector by governments of 
developing nations and emerging economies.  
 
11.  Practical and tested experience of advising governments in their management of the 
petroleum  sector  is  required,  as  well  as  recognition  of  the  government  of  Cambodia’s 
development priorities. The advisor will have excellent communication skills and the ability to 
provide  written  and  readily  understandable  advisory  briefs  and  presentations  as  well  as 
immediate counsel on sector matters.  
 
12.  The petroleum sector advisor shall report to the chairman, vice chairman, and director-
general, as needed, but will be required to be available to provide advice to other senior officials 
of the government, as required, and to the staff of the CNPA in general.

12  Appendix 3   
 
13.  The CNPA will provide basic office accommodation for the advisor at its offices and 
access to CNPA files, papers, and reports as are reasonably necessary for the provision of the 
services.
